Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: High-Performance Software for Large-Scale Modeling of Binding Equilibria

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Living organisms are regulated by specific interactions among proteins and other macromolecules. Cancer and genetic diseases are due to altered interactions caused by mutations. Cellular organelles and viruses spontaneously build themselves from the ordered assembly of component molecules. While a complete understanding remains elusive, these and many other phenomena fundamentally rest on the ability of molecules to recognize and bind specifically to other molecules. The general principles of molecular recognition are being employed to design new drugs, chemical catalysts, and advanced materials. Computer models offer an important mean to disentangle and analyze molecular interactions and to produce quantitative predictions. The main objective of the project is to develop novel algorithms to model molecular recognition processes at atomic resolution on modern parallel computer architectures. This research seeks to increase the speed of the calculations and expand hardware support to enable the screening of larger sets of drug candidates and the study of multiple protein mutations under various conditions. The increased accuracy and availability of modeling software technologies by a larger community will lead to new ideas and research approaches, and ultimately to new discoveries in medicine, chemistry and material science. This effort will contribute to the establishment of in silico means to evaluate environmental and clinical claims. For example computational evidences on toxicity of substances can inform public policy in the same way that, for instance, atmospheric models are currently used for global climate projections.

The project targets the Binding Energy Distribution Analysis Method (BEDAM, for short), an accurate model of molecular binding, currently limited by computational performance. Outcomes of this research include deployment the BEDAM model for the first time on General Purpose Graphical Processing Units (GPGPU) and Many Integrated Core (MIC) massively parallel architectures. To this end, the mathematical formulation of the model will be tuned to best utilize the features of these modern computing architectures. Specialized recursive computational geometry algorithms will be developed to extract from the parallel hardware near optimal performance. Robust automated tools for the processing of molecular models and their analysis will be put in place for large scale applications. Accessible user interfaces will be implemented to ensure wide applicability and adoption of the software. These software applications will be distributed under an open source license to promote sharing and community contributions. Student research assistants form an integral part of the research team. While contributing meaningfully to scientific research, students from challenging socioeconomic backgrounds will acquire computer programming and software maintenance skills useful to enter the high tech job market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During brain development neurons make connections to form brain structures. Viruses self-assemble in infected cells and go on to attack other cells. The detailed molecular mechanisms at the basis of fascinating processes such as these are still largely beyond our grasp. We know, however, that they fundamentally depend on the ability of molecules to recognize and bind specifically to other molecules. Computer models to study the interactions between molecules are still very much in their infancy. This is in contrast to the routine use of computers to, say, design bridges, guide space probes, and recognize faces in airport lines. The challenge is that molecules are flexible and can change their shapes to adapt to other molecules. While it is very hard to determine computationally whether two molecules of known structure have complementary shapes, it is even harder to predict the degree to which they can change their shapes to fit each other. 
Theoretical and computational scientists have made great strides towards the development of models of molecular recognition incorporating molecular motion. These are now used to, for example, discover drugs with fewer side effects, to optimize pharmaceutical preparations, and to design more efficient and environmentally friendly chemical catalysts. One major challenge is that these applications require fast super-computers with enough capacity to to simulate the motion of tens of thousands of interacting atoms. The power and cost of super-computers has severely limited simulation time and the number of chemical systems that can be studied. It has recently become possible to program graphical processing units of widespread gaming PC's to turn them them, effectively, into super-computers. This work, generously financed by the National Science Foundation, has made it possible to implement onto graphical processing units an advanced computational model of molecular recognition. This will enable the modeling of a greater number of systems, of greater complexity, and at a higher level of detail.
The main outcome of the project has been the development of new computing algorithms for graphical processing units suitable for molecular simulations and in, particular, for the study of molecular recognition processes. The software developed is freely accessible so that computational chemists, as well as scientists in other fields, can use it or adapt it for new applications. Six publications have resulted from the project so far, and two more are under preparation, on such topics as the study of protein complexes responsible for disrupting connections between neurons in children with autism and the discovery of anti-viral drugs, as well as high performance computer algorithms and grid computing. In addition to the scientific and technological goals, a central activity of this project has been the involvement of underrepresented undergraduate students to give them the experience and technological skills to succeed in the workforce, while at the same time fostering their interest in science. The project has employed four undergraduate students, including two women, whose outstanding contributions earned them co-authorship in two peer-reviewed publications. By participating in the project the students have acquired skills in computer programming, computer administration, and software management valuable to succeed in the modern job market.
